author: Richard Hartley-Parkinson
title: Man got beaten up for waking passenger up at wrong station
text:
Sam Pearce, 24, attacked Benjamin Kerr on a train (Picture: National) A man had his nose broken because a fellow passenger said he ‘made him look stupid’ when he woke up at the wrong station.
Sam Pearce, 24, threw Benjamin Kerr out of a carriage, kicked him in the chest and punched him multiple times in the head, breaking his nose.
Beware of Aldi scam offering you free £65 vouchers towards your shopping Benjamin, 39, had fallen asleep during the journey at around 1.30am and awoke at St Albans, believing that the train had arrived at its final destination and nudged Pearce awake.
But the pair soon realised that the station wrong, Pearce became ‘frustrated’ and then walked through the train to find Benjamin before attacking him on the Thameslink train on 17 June 2015.
On Friday Pearce, from Harrow, north London, was jailed for a year after a jury found him guilty of assaulting and causing actual bodily harm to Benjamin, from Flitwick, Bedfordshire.
He threw him off the train and left him with a broken nose (Picture: National) British Transport Police Sergeant Stephen Bartlett said: ‘Pearce displayed overwhelming levels of aggression during this unprovoked and vicious assault.
‘His defence was that he was getting back at the victim for making him look ‘stupid’.
‘This is a totally unreasonable claim and he should be ashamed for his callous and reckless actions.
Railway line blocked for 48 hours after derailing ‘The victim was simply trying to help Pearce by making sure he left the train at the final stop.
‘He was apologetic for his mistake and was not expecting the violence that came next.
‘As you can imagine this was an utterly terrifying experience for the victim who was left shaking on the platform.
‘He thankfully sustained no long term injuries as a result of this assault.
‘Pearce’s sentence reflects the severity of his actions and reinforces the message that attacks like this will always be dealt with severely.
‘And we will do everything on our power to bring those responsible to justice.’
